text: how does the u.s. see its place in the
world that's the question the Pew
Research Center is asked and here's what
they found for the first time in 40
years a majority of Americans say the US
plays a less important role on the
international stage but let's not assume
that means Americans want their country
to get out there and do more fifty-two
percent another record high say the US
should just mind its own business
globally when it does come to foreign
policy many of the public's top goals
are driven by domestic concerns now
let's take that top concern and drill
down a bit further fifty percent of
americans say the use of military drones
makes the u.s. safer from terrorism
that's compared to only thirty-one
percent who say the war in afghanistan
hats
now it's no surprise that most Americans
want their country to be the only
military superpower but more and more
see China as number one in economic
strength now while we're in Asia let's
take a look at something else more young
americans think that region has greater
importance for the u.s. than europe does
but not so for older Americans now in
terms of how Americans see other
countries this hasn't changed much over
all the Pew study selected 12 countries
and rank them according to the
percentage of Americans who viewed them
favorably even if most Americans want
the u.s. to mind its own business on
many foreign issues that's not a
rallying call for isolationism
seventy-seven percent say it's a good
thing for the u.s. to have more
involvement in the global economy David
Botti BBC News Washington
